Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Automatic and Non-intrusive Screening for Potential Viral Disease Carriers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Viral disease outbreaks such as Ebola epidemic can be a serious concern for the general public. Many these viral diseases cause a temperature increase in human body and can be visually detected from infrared images. This project develops an intelligent system to automatically detect human body temperature for non-intrusively screening potential viral disease carriers from a crowd. The system is built on recent advances in computer vision technologies and thermal infrared sensors.

This project addresses an important and interesting application of computer vision. The research leads to development of a prototype system that can be deployed in a public pace to automatically measure human body temperatures from facial images. The research work includes discovering how to localize the facial features accurately and precisely from both visible and infrared images for the purpose of accurate measure of body temperatures and reducing false alarms in screening of potential viral disease carriers. The key approach utilizes both visible light and infrared spectra to achieve a robust solution. It can also process multiple people in a crowd non-intrusively and speed up the screening process. The research in this project can address the critical need for screening of viral disease carriers, and advance the study on machine vision algorithms applicable to an important and practical problem related to public health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on improving key point detection in thermography and handling multiple people or a crowd, which will make a great impact on airport screening for potential viral disease carriers. The research on the project can reduce false alarms and speed up the screening process significantly. The project also explores the recently developed thermal imaging sensors with extremely low price and great mobility, making an impact on reducing the cost greatly for public screening, and deploying the mobile platforms anywhere and anytime.

 

A dual-camera setup is adopted in the research and development to attack the difficulty in detecting key points in thermography. A couple of mappings between the visible light and infrared sensors are computed and calibrated off-line, and then used for online processing. Built on the state-of-the-art technologies for key point detection in visible light images, the research explores how to operate the portable sensors optimally and conveniently, including the optimal distances to capture visual data, and the optimal number of subjects that can be acquired simultaneously and processed in parallel. The developed system has been tested on a number of subjects in different situations for validation of the algorithms.  

 

The exploration in this project forces advanced computer vision technologies to meet a real application with critical need right now and in the future, inspiring computer vision researchers to put more efforts for solving practical and important problems with great societal impact and benefits.
